bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: Porgy and Bess was a three act "folk Opera" produced by The Theatre Guild at the Alvin Theatre, New York City, in 1927. The Opera was taken directly from a book by Dubose Heyward titled Porgy, with lyrics and music by Ira and George Gershwin. The opera revolves around Porgy, a physically-challenged African-American black beggar who lives and works in a Charleston tenement called Catfish Row and who loves the beautiful but weak-willed Bess. Bess is the mistress of the vicious Crown, but when Crown flees after murdering a man, she goes to live with Porgy. On Crown's return porgy fights with him and kills him. Porgy is taken to jail, and while there Bess is lured away by the drug peddler, Sportin' Life. When Porgy gets out of jail, he leaves Catfish Row to find Bess. This is where the play ends. The play remains one of the greatest of all American folk dramas.

Robert Breen was the first Person to arrange postwar United States and Soviet cultural "changes. He also helped to bring federal financing to the performing arts. His greatest success was on the international stage in 1952. He directed and co-produced with Blevins Davis the critically acclaimed revival of Porgy and Bess. It toured twenty-nine countries in four years. The following is a brief account of the opera's successful tours through North and South America and Europe.

The United States performances began in Chicago and had a slow start because of the summer heat and the preoccupation with the Republican National Convention. But, before long the tour became a huge success. Critics called the performances of Porgy and Bess, "the best sung version yet,"' and by the end of their stay in Chicago the cast was performing to standing room only crowds.

From Chicago, the troupe traveled to Vienna, Austria for the opening of their European tour on September 7, 1952. In the past, Vienna had never been very receptive to American opera, but after Porgy and Bess, attitudes changed dramatically. The crowds went wild: they had never seen anything like it before in a theater. The next stop was Berlin and there, too, the audiences loved Porgy and Bess. It became the main event for a month-long festival. The reactions of the audiences were extraordinary, even though many could not understand what was being spoken or sung.

Europeans were not the only ones to notice the amazing success of Porgy and Bess. In the United States people were also taking notice of Porgy and Bess, including President Dwight Eisenhower. He created an emergency fund with an annual appropriation of five million dollars. This fund was used to finance and promote "American" cultural activities, such as Porgy and Bess. Half the money went to theater productions. The economics of production demanded full houses, so when there was a period of empty seats in Europe, Billy Rose proposed bringing the tour home to the United States. But before going home, they traveled to Paris for one last performance. The reactions were the same as in Vienna and Berlin. Gendarmes were needed to keep those without tickets from crashing the gates. Critics called Porgy and Bess, "A masterpiece ... one doesn't have to say more. ,2 After Paris, the troupe returned to perform at the Ziegfeld Theatre in New York City. While there, the cast performed 305 shows and while still in New York, the popularity of Porgy and Bess picked up in Europe. The troupe was invited to revisit Paris, intending to stay only three weeks, but demand kept the opera performing for an additional seven weeks. From Paris, the opera moved to Zagreb, Yugoslavia. This was the first time American singers were invited behind the Iron Curtain.

Their next stop was Egypt, first Alexandria and then Cairo. The first performance in Alexandria was on New Year's Eve, and critics were skeptical about the shows success, but the cast played to a packed house, while hundreds more were turned away. From Alexandria, they traveled to Cairo, where, once again, they were a huge success. Next, the troupe traveled to Tel Aviv, Israel, where they performed eight shows at the Habimah Theatre. People literally tackled the ticket takers so that they could get inside the theater.

From Israel, the opera traveled to Barcelona, Spain. Here, they performed for ten days, and critics called Porgy and Bess "the best thing seen in Barcelona in twenty years."' From there they traveled to Italy, first to Milan and the world-renowned Teatro Alla Scala. For many in the cast it was a lifelong dream to perform in the Teatro Alla Scala. They did not let anyone down -- they performed as never before. It was the first time an American company had been invited to one of the world's premier opera houses. After Milan, the cast performed in Genoa and Florence, Lausanne, Marseilles, and back to Italy to perform in Turin and Rome. After Italy, they traveled to Zurich, and finished this leg of the European tour in Brussels and Antwerp.
The troupe then changed direction, traveling south to Rio de Janeiro, and Lima. The audiences in South America thought Porgy and Bess was a revelation, and worthy of unrestricted applause.

From South America, they went to the Soviet Union, first Leningrad and then Moscow. There were some misunderstandings on opening night in Leningrad because audiences had trouble understanding things such as the buzzard over Porgy's abode and the open attitudes about sexual passion. The Russians appeared to suffer from culture shock. By the end of the Leningrad tour, however, the cast was once again a huge success and played to full houses and enthusiastic audiences. Next, they appeared in Moscow where the cast felt more comfortable because the theater audiences were more accepting than the ones in Leningrad. On the second night the cast was honored by the attendance of the three most important Soviet politicians: Nikita Khrushchev, Nikolai Bulganin, and Vyacheslav Molotov. This was a rare occurrence because the leaders rarely attended public performances: when they did, it had always been on the last night.

The next stops were again behind the Iron Curtain, Warsaw, and Prague. The performances were a huge success and once again tickets sold out before the performances began. After the troupe left Warsaw and Prague, they traveled to Germany, where they performed in Munich, Stuttgart, Dtisseldorf, and Hamburg. From Germany they traveled to Rotterdam, Netherlands, Aachus, Denmark and back to the Netherlands, this time in Amsterdam, where the tour ended on June 3, 1956.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Posters are arranged alphabetically according to the country where the performances were held.
